Not the risque ones from the 70s, but the more demure ones from the 1950s that I bought five for a dollar at strip mall, paperback bookshops. I grew out of my romance-reading phase, but for some reason I kept one of those books from my teen years: Under the Stars of Paris. Decades later, who knows why, I looked up the book and discovered that the author, Mary Burchell, was the pen name for Ida Cook, an opera enthusiast who used that passion, along with money from writing romances, to help Jewish people escape from Europe at the start of WWII. This memoir is heavy on the opera story - Ida and her sister Louise lived and breathed opera - and very modest when it comes to their efforts. I fell in love with MI've read this book half a dozen times, at least, but it has been years (decades?) between the last time I read it and this one. I fell in love with Moon Tiger when I worked at the Elliott Bay Book Company in the early 1990s. I'd never read a novel like it before. The shifting points of view. Not just between characters, but between first and third person for the same character. Claudia, the main character, is tough and somewhat unkind, judgemental, tender at her very center, and determined in a way I'd never encountered before. It's interesting to think of who I was when I first read this book and who am I now, rereading it. Now I've known women like Claudia. I've read stories far trickier with their handling of POV. What I realize is that this book most likely stayed with me all this time because Penelope Lively is simply an excellent writer. I've read almost all of her novels, and her characters always ring true. In this case, Claudia is never not Claudia. Even when her heart breaks, it breaks in only the way it could break for this specific character. When she is selfish, the selfishness is hers and no one else's. I admire that ability to let a character be who she is, since I'm the kind of person who always wants everyone to be happy - even in books! Moon Tiger has so much to offer, about the way we look at world history and the way we look at our own personal history. About how we see our lives and how others see our lives. Simply writing this I'm already looking forward to reading Moon Tiger again....more

I had an old hardcover copy with gilt letters on the spine that belonged to my Great-Aunt Emma. As an aspiring writer, of course I related to Jo. But I remember all of the sisters' stories. What I didn't remember was how progressive LITTLE WOMEN is for its time. Yes, it's mired in traditional female roles (it is of it's time, after all), and yes I realize I'm about to quote a section that uses the term "old maid," but there were parts that made me pause. That I don't recall, perhaps because as a kid I didn't understand how unusual they were. For example, in talking about marriage, Mrs. March declares it's better to be "happy old maids than unhappy wives" and advises, "Make this home happy, so that you may be fit for homes of your own, if they are offered you, and contented here if they are not." Basically, she's saying it's okay to be single, she just wants her girls to be happy. In 1868! I also admired the tongue-in-cheek humor that also went over my head when I was young. The sisters are funny, loving, loyal, and oh so complex. What a pleasure it was to read this again in mid-life. I can't wait to read it in another 10 years and see what stands out for me then....more

review: This book changed my life. I was 21 and backpacking through Europe. I'd been an avid reader all my life, but the usual wonderful kid stuff and otherwiThis book changed my life. I was 21 and backpacking through Europe. I'd been an avid reader all my life, but the usual wonderful kid stuff and otherwise romances (teen and then Harlequin) - the books I'd been exposed to growing up in small towns. I picked up a Jackie Collins novel in Greece, and after reading it decided I would never mindlessly grab another book off a hostel bookcase again! On a train, I told my woes to the guy from New Zealand sitting next to me. He reached into his backpack and pulled out 3 books. One was HOTEL DU LAC. So this was what a novel could accomplish! I was mesmerized by this quiet, painful, elegant story of disappointment, exile, human nature, and love. Jump ahead 35 years. I'm in Copenhagen with my husband, and we turn down a narrow street and see a row of green metal carts containing used books. We have stumbled upon Vangsgaards Rare Books. What a treasure! I perused each bin of fifty cent and dollar books, English mingling with Danish, and to my delight I came upon a pretty pocket edition of my beloved HOTEL DU LAC. Rereading it all these years later only cements Anita Brookner in my mind as a superb literary portrait artist. There is nothing quite like the first time you read a book that moves you, for whatever reason. It can be just as special to reread that book and remember a time in your life when the world was first opening up to you....more

It think her Mas Arai series is exquisite with insight and subtlety. Clark and Division has the insights, but the story isn't subtle - nor should it be. Too little has been written for mainstream audiences about the imprisonment of Japanese and Japanese Americans during WWII. Most of us read Farewell to Manzanar in school at some point; and that was enough, as far as our educators were concerned. It wasn't. Because this story is so complex. I'm not talking about what the government did. That was woefully straightforward. But the way the Japanese community lived, existed, and rebuilt itself both in and out of the prison camps is multi-layered. In this case, the story focuses on those people who were allowed to leave the camps during the war so long as they relocated to the Midwest, where they couldn't easily serve as spies for Japan. Yes, this is a crime novel, but the crime is a tool Hirahara uses to explore family, displacement, race, love, identity, and so much more. As always with her novels, she doesn't go for mega-drama. This book about twins conjoined at their heads turned out to be so much more than a story about biological outliers. Their physical situation is a tool for exploring larger themes of identity and individuality, as well as academia and nationalism, as the sisters pass through adolescence and their early adult years on the inner rim of the wars that broke up Yugoslavia in the 1990s. I was fascinated by the details of daily life in a former Eastern Bloc country on the verge of independence, and I found the sisters' story engaging, from the intimacies they had no choice but to share, to their jagged relationships with their family and friends. review: I read the first volume in this trilogy when I was in my 20s, and I've wanted to read the whole trilogy since then. A few months ago, I started over wI read the first volume in this trilogy when I was in my 20s, and I've wanted to read the whole trilogy since then. A few months ago, I started over with Volume 1. One of my main goals in reading this was to get back my attention span. The trilogy is 900+ pages, and I knew it would require my brain to focus and recall, which I find harder to do these days. What a pleasure it was to luxuriate in this story for nearly 3 months (yes, that's how long it took me!). I followed Guy and Harriet Pringle to Rumania at the start of WWII. And from there to Greece with various characters meandering in and out of the plot, showing up after a long absence and pleasantly surprising me as if I was running into an old friend. I also got a new education when it comes to WWII history. Manning is a writer who should not be forgotten. Her observations are concise and authentic, and her ability to capture the day-to-day living of expatriates in a country on the verge of war made me marvel at the significance of the mundane. On top of that, her descriptions are exquisite. I lost count of how many gorgeous descriptions of weather alone that I highlighted. Her ability to capture sense of place made me pause often to reread and admire. Was this book worth the half dozen shorter books I could have read instead in the same amount of time?
